p: In the Zanthoxylum genus, several biological activities—larvicidal [ 3], trypanocidal [ 4], anti-tumor [ 5], anti-psoriasis [ 6], and anti-inflammatory [ 7], among others—have been described. In Brazil, people of the state of Rondônia use the tea from leaves and roots of Zanthoxylium sp. to relieve toothache [ 8]. Additionally, the species Z. simullans and Z. chalybeum are used for the treatment of malaria [ 9, 10].
